results.title: Maroondah Dam
results.brief_description:
Silent 1950s home movie footage of a family outing to the Maroondah Dam in the Upper Yarra Valley. Includes images of the landscape and boating facilities. Filmed by portrait photographer Athol Adams.
Athol Adams footage is courtesy of Jenny and Owen Peake.

results.title: Ngan Jila: house of riches
results.brief_description:
Ngan Jila, or House of Riches, is an extraordinary piece of architecture. Designed by Renzo piano and widely known as Centre Culturel Tjibaou (CCT), the building is intended as a gesture of reconciliation from the French Government to the Kanak people.
The CCT is creating the first museum collection of contemporary South Pacific art, but what does this entail? Ngan Jila exposes the work of artists in this field, and explores its dynamic and cross-cultural nature.

results.title: Tal Farlow
results.brief_description: Jazz guitarist Tal Farlow provides the background music to Lye’s final film, which, although begun in the 1950s, was not recommenced until the 1980s. Unfortunately he died before completing it. It contains vertical white scratches as well as geometric white scratches on black. It was completed by Lye’s assistant Steve Jones under the supervision of Ann Lye. Supported in part by a grant from the Queen Elizabeth II Arts Council of New Zealand.

results.title: Packing apples for export
results.brief_description:
Film explains how to correctly pack and store apples for export to Enlgand on ships. Features footage of early automated fruit processing technology, as well as women sorting through apples and packing them. Nice shots, also, of people picking apples and placing them in steel buckets. Classic apple-picking imagery with rich reds and greens. Some slow-motion footage of ‘expert’ demonstrating how to wrap an apple before packing. End of film shot at docks with numerous crates being hiosted onto ships. Narration is upbeat and light.

Beautiful illustrated title and end credits featuring text-over-apples.

results.title: May 1955 pig carcase competition
results.brief_description:
Propaganda piece highlighting Victoria’s development as the foremost producer of pork in Australia. Competition received a record number of entries and the winning score of 93/100 for a carcase was the highest total ever in Australia. Winner was a ‘new Australian’ from Italy.

The cracases are beautifully displayed and almost fetishised as if in an art gallery. Everyone involved takes great joy, interest and pride in the meat displayed to an amusingly earnest extent. The images are high-contrast with vibrant reds and greens. A combination of the above provides a beautifully surreal quality to the piece.

Amusing sound grabs from narration such as “Here we have a veritable paradise of pork”.

Interesting ‘The End’ illustration, good for Postcards, etc.

results.title: Taming the red swamp
results.brief_description: Vision only. Film seems to be about the techniques employed to make waterlogged land usable for crops. Footage includes old-style farm vehicles and machinery being used to achieve this. Nice shot of 6 new red tractors driving through the terrain. Also features an amusing moment where two men push a large poll into the ground to prove how soft the soil is. General shots of cattle are scattered throughout. Nice, kitsch begining and end illustrated titles. Good ‘The End’, possibly for postcard.

results.title: Spaghetti
results.brief_description: Created as part of Victoria University Multimedia’s After Effects course, this short piece shows, through simple animation, live action and video - the process of making pasta with tomato sauce.
results.description: Created as part of Victoria University Multimedia’s After Effects course, this short piece shows, through simple animation, live action and video - the process of making pasta with tomato sauce.

results.title: Corps de deux
results.brief_description: A stylish looking short filmed without dialogue in the heart of Melbourne’s CBD. Images of the ‘boys’ on the town are inter-cut with more serious scenes of martial arts that have a dance-like quality. The student filmmaker describes it as ‘a conceptual piece that explores opposing aspects of the male psyche’
